title: Syed Nayeemuddin
text:
Syed Nayeemuddin (born 1944), known as Nayeem, is an Indian <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="coach%20%28sports%29">coach</a> and former player. He played for and was <a href="Captain%20%28association%20football%29">captain</a> of the <a href="India%20national%20football%20team">Indian national team</a> and has managed <a href="Mahindra%20United">Mahindra United</a>, <a href="Brothers%20Union">Brothers Union</a>, <a href="Dhaka%20Mohammedan">Dhaka Mohammedan</a>, and <a href="Bangladesh%20national%20football%20team">Bangladesh national team</a>. He is the only sportsperson to win both the <a href="Arjuna%20Award">Arjuna Award</a>, recognising his contribution to Indian football. He received the award by the <a href="Government%20of%20India">Government of India</a> in 1997. and <a href="Dronacharya%20Award">Dronacharya Award</a> for football.
As a player, he captained the <a href="India%20national%20football%20team">India</a> that won a bronze medal at the <a href="1970%20Asian%20Games">1970 Asian Games</a>.
Managerial career.
Nayeemuddin was appointed coach of India national team in 1997. He won the <a href="South%20Asian%20Football%20Federation">South Asian Football Federation</a> Cup by beating the <a href="Maldives%20national%20football%20team">Maldives</a> 5–1 and reached the semi-finals of the <a href="Nehru%20Cup%20International%20Football%20Tournament">Nehru Cup</a> for the first time. His time in charge of the national team was blighted with no practice matches between September 1997 and November 1998 before the <a href="1998%20Asian%20Games">1998 Asian Games</a>. He managed the team in <a href="Football%20at%20the%201998%20Asian%20Games%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20tournament">1998 Asian Games</a> held at <a href="Bangkok">Bangkok</a>, where they reached second round.
His role with India ended after the games in December 1998. His second role with India began when he succeeded <a href="Sukhwinder%20Singh%20%28football%20coach%29">Sukhwinder Singh</a> as India coach in 2005, but left in 2006 after poor performances against <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan</a> and <a href="Yemen%20national%20football%20team">Yemen</a> when qualifying for the <a href="2007%20AFC%20Asian%20Cup%20qualification">2007 Asian Cup</a>. Since 2007 to 2017, he was the head coach of <a href="Brothers%20Union">Brothers Union</a>, Dhaka. He has previously managed <a href="Bengal%20Mumbai%20FC">Bengal Mumbai FC</a> in the Mumbai Football League.
